results.headline: Review: In ‘The Human Experiment,’ We’re the Unwitting Guinea Pigs
results.summary_short: This documentary by Don Hardy and Dana Nachman explores the perils of the largely unregulated and potentially dangerous substances we encounter each day.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Human Experiment

results.headline: Review: In ‘The Dead Lands,’ the Maori Fight for Survival
results.summary_short: Set in New Zealand, this drama focuses on long-ago warriors struggling to acquit themselves honorably in combat.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hautoa

results.headline: Review: In ‘Beyond the Reach,’ Michael Douglas as a Greedy Ogre in the Desert
results.summary_short: The film also features Jeremy Irvine as a desert guide turned prey, pursued by Mr. Douglas’s snarling, ogrelike character.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Beyond the Reach

results.headline: Review: In ‘Antarctic Edge,’ a Region of Retreating Ice
results.summary_short: This documentary about a scarcely charted place underlines the sheer labor of exploration and the global dangers posed by shrinking sea ice.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Antarctic Edge: 70° South

results.headline: Review: In ‘Alex of Venice,’ a Career Workaholic Learns to Shoulder Family Burdens
results.summary_short: Mary Elizabeth Winstead plays a character much like Dustin Hoffman’s in “Kramer vs. Kramer” in Chris Messina’s directorial debut.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Alex of Venice

results.headline: Review: ‘Human Highway’ and ‘Muddy Track,’ Whimsical ’80s Artifacts From Neil Young
results.summary_short: Given only minimal screenings in the past, two movies in the playfully named Bernard Shakey Film Retrospective at the IFC Center reveal different elements of Mr. Young’s persona.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Muddy Track

results.headline: Review: ‘Closer to the Moon’ Recounts a Bizarre Bit of Romanian History
results.summary_short: A group of disillusioned Jewish former disciples of Romanian Communism (Vera Farmiga and Mark Strong, among others) cook up a plot to rob a state bank in 1959.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Closer to the Moon

results.headline: Review: ‘Child 44,’ a Secret-Police Thriller in Soviet Russia
results.summary_short: In “Child 44,” set in the 1950s, a Soviet secret-police agent exiled to a remote town with his wife tries to track a serial killer of boys.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Child 44

results.headline: Review: ‘Below Dreams,’ the Human Struggle in the City Below Sea Level
results.summary_short: Against the backdrop of New Orleans, three individuals starting at the bottom strive for a future.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Below Dreams

results.headline: Review: ‘Rebels of the Neon God’ Gets a New York Screening
results.summary_short: A retrospective devoted to the director Tsai Ming-liang offers the first real screening of his debut film in the United States.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rebels of the Neon God

results.headline: Review: In ‘The Harvest,’ Love Is Wielded With a Chill
results.summary_short: In this film, an orphaned girl’s friendship with an ill boy complicates family dynamics.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Harvest

results.headline: Review: In ‘Lost River,’ by Ryan Gosling, Surreal Scenes of Urban Decline
results.summary_short: Bleak Michigan scenery is the backdrop for a form of horror film that ponders people and places left behind in the name of progress.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lost River

results.headline: Review: In ‘Ex Machina,’ a Mogul Fashions the Droid of His Dreams
results.summary_short: In Alex Garland’s film, an Internet mogul creates a gorgeous robot named Ava, with unsettling consequences.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ex Machina

results.headline: Review: In ‘Clouds of Sils Maria,’ a Celebration Turns Into a Memorial
results.summary_short: “Clouds of Sils Maria,” directed by Olivier Assayas, examines female friendships, female rivalries, tabloid notoriety and the loss of privacy in the Internet age.

results.headline: Review: ‘The Sisterhood of Night,’ a Dark Tale of Small-Town Hysteria
results.summary_short: The film centers on three high school girls who form an invitation-only clique that meets in the woods after dark.

results.headline: Review: ‘The Living’ Wades Into Domestic Abuse and Revenge
results.summary_short: A husband beats his wife and a hit man is hired in this drama about a difficult marriage.

results.headline: Review: ‘Reset,’ an Elliptical Tale of Breaking With the Past
results.summary_short: “Reset,” an offbeat film written and directed by Paul Bojack, tells the story of a man who repeatedly returns to his hometown with the intention of avoiding anyone he once knew.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Reset

results.headline: Review: ‘Kill Me Three Times,’ and Then Some, Set in a Murderous Surf Town
results.summary_short: The movie recalls “Pulp Fiction” in its collection of human types and its surreal violence.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kill Me Three Times

results.headline: Review: In ‘The Longest Ride,’ the Nicholas Sparks Brand Endures
results.summary_short: A young couple from different worlds find the road to enduring love is paved with complications, some preposterous, some life-threatening.

results.headline: Review: In ‘Song From the Forest,’ Louis Sarno Links Africa and America
results.summary_short: A father-son relationship, music and the Bayaka of the Central African Republic are central to this documentary.
